pr_title: PLANNER-1613 toList() and toSet() constraint collectors

timeline.message: PLANNER-1613 toList() and toSet() constraint collectors
PLANNER-1613 Documentation: toList() and toSet() constraint collectors
PLANNER-1613 Documentation: toList() and toSet() constraint collectors
PLANNER-1613 Documentation: toList() and toSet() constraint collectors

timeline.author: ge0ffrey
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -554,4 +561,171 @@ private static Runnable innerCountDistinctLong(CountDistinctLongResultContainer
     private ConstraintCollectors() {
     }
 
+    // ************************************************************************
+    // toCollection
+    // ************************************************************************
+
+    /**
+     * Creates constraint collector that will return matched facts as a collection.

timeline.bodyText: Do we need toCollection? When in doubt leave it out. I 'd rather start with just toSet() and toList() until someone complains of the lack of toCollection(). Wdyt?
timeline.author: ge0ffrey
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -554,4 +561,171 @@ private static Runnable innerCountDistinctLong(CountDistinctLongResultContainer
     private ConstraintCollectors() {
     }
 
+    // ************************************************************************
+    // toCollection
+    // ************************************************************************
+
+    /**
+     * Creates constraint collector that will return matched facts as a collection.
+     *
+     * @param collectionFunction never null, provides new instance of the target collection with given initial capacity
+     * @param <A> type of the matched fact, matching the type of elements in the resulting collection
+     * @param <Result> type of the target collection
+     * @return never null
+     */
+    public static <A, Result extends Collection<A>> UniConstraintCollector<A, ?, Result> toCollection(

replies.bodyText: I consider it useful for when you want a stable iteration order, so you request toCollection(TreeSet::new).
replies.author: triceo

replies.bodyText:
Agreed, or to pick your collection type. Keep it indeed.
This is the special case though. The toList() is the normal case. So toList() gets a full proper javadoc (they others can use "As defined by"). Wdyt?
replies.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: So, I guess we want toCollection(constructor), but not toCollection()?
replies.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText:
javadocs :)
Especially for toList() as that's the main one.
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: Yeah, the Javadoc is on toCollection() now.
replies.author: triceo

replies.bodyText: Add at least a "As defined by ..."
replies.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText:
Thinking aloud: The method name doesn't indicate it's used as the undo operation.
How about calling it to undoToCollection?
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: This is not the undo. This is the finisher, which takes the incremental container and turns it into a final immutable product.
replies.author: triceo

replies.bodyText:
Agreed, then the name is correct. I interpreted "finish" as last part that is common, not as finisher.
Maybe toCollectionFinisher? Although name is fine now.
replies.author: ge0ffrey
